awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Morphology and Property Correlations of Chemically Doped 1D Conjugated Polymer Aggregates
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Polymers Program in the Division of Materials Research and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The research objective of this CAREER project is to gain fundamental knowledge of the correlation between morphology at the nanoscale and optoelectronic properties of chemically doped one-dimensional conducting polymer aggregates. The planned research and educational activities have broad impacts by tackling current national needs in both materials and human workforce development. The knowledge gained in the project will promote rational design of more efficient organic materials for electronic applications, as well as more efficient processing and fabrication techniques for future organic electronic devices.  With the current world organic electronics market size expected to grow significantly in the next decade, enhancements on just a fraction of the organic electronic materials could have an impact on US and global economy.  

This program also provides a platform for participating students to gain expertise from interdisciplinary fields including materials science, chemistry, and surface science. Hands-on activities involving polymer science and nanoscience will be offered to K-8 students for early exposure to scientific topics. High-school polymer nanoscience workshops will provide students hands-on experience on preparing and characterizing functional nanostructures.  Extra efforts will be devoted to recruiting and involving underrepresented and economically disadvantaged K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students into these outreach activities.  Successful execution of these integrated research and education activities will enhance diversity in US scientific research and inspire more K-12 and undergraduate students to pursue STEM careers.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The systematic local morphology-property correlation of non-doped and doped 1D conjugated polymer aggregates gained by AFM-based methods is the primary goal of this project.  To achieve this goal, monolayer and multi-layer conjugated polymer nanowhiskers are chosen as the model systems in this program because most of the polymer molecules within monolayer nanowhiskers are surface molecules that can be directly investigated by surface characterization tools. Multi-layer nanowhiskers will be subsequently studied in a "layer-by-layer" manner on the basis of what was learned from monolayer nanowhiskers. Local morphology-property relationship for doped and non-doped conjugated polymer nanowhiskers will be analyzed using AFM and its advanced modes. The doping reaction in solution will be systematically studied by UV-vis spectroscopy to reveal the influences of many parameters, particularly the aggregation forms, on the chemical doping reaction kinetics. The charge transport in and between 1D conjugated polymer aggregates will also be interrogated at nanometer scale.  This program is expected to reveal structure and property fluctuations at nano- to micrometer scales that are otherwise hidden in ensemble measurements.  The conductivity studies within and between nanowhiskers will elucidate the interrelated roles of defect sites, ordered/disordered domains, connection points, and chemical doping on the charge transport of conjugated polymer materials. The results of the chemical doping reaction kinetic dependence on the reaction conditions, especially conjugate polymer microscopic aggregation forms, will supply practical solution-based applications with crucial macroscopic doping reaction kinetics information that is largely missing so far. The comprehensive understanding of the chemical doping of conjugated polymers accumulated in this program will enable researchers in this field to seek suitable strategies based on concrete organic doping knowledge rather than through empirical trials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Organic electronics based on conjugated polymer has a variety of applications in displays, sensors, organic solar cells, and flexible electronics. Besides synthesizing new compounds, the optoelectronic properties of conjugated polymers can be readily modified by changing their morphology or chemical doping. With NSF support, this project studied the aggregation process of conjugated polymers into nanowires, chemical doping of conjugated polymer, as well as the interplay between aggregation and chemical doping.

We have demonstrated that chemical doping actively promotes the aggregation of P3HT in solution. Moreover, we have observed a remarkable 1000-fold increase in the rate of doping reactions in solution when P3HT is in its aggregated state compared to when it is fully solubilized. Additionally, we have made a significant discovery regarding the solution doping process of P3HT using F4TCNQ, a commonly used p-dopant for P3HT. Our findings indicate that the solution doping of P3HT with F4TCNQ necessitates a pre-aggregation step for the P3HT molecules. In contrast, fully solubilized P3HT does not exhibit a reaction with F4TCNQ even after mixed for hours. This insight sheds light on the mechanism of chemical doping in P3HT and contributes to a deeper understanding of its behavior. Furthermore, our investigations into the aggregation of conjugated polymers have led to the development of monolayer nanowires of P3HT. These pristine and doped nanowires have been thoroughly characterized using techniques such as atomic force microscopy (AFM) and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM). Additionally, we have successfully fabricated macroscopic conjugated polymer fibers utilizing an external electric field. Notably, our fibers can reach sizes of several centimeters, representing the largest fibers reported to date produced using electric field. These achievements highlight the potential for scalable production of conjugated polymer fibers with promising applications.

Other significant research results are based on electrochemical doping of conjugated polymers in organic electrochemical transistors (OECT). We studied the stability of OECT devices under cross-linking and provided constructive recommendations on the operation conditions for these devices. We also gave a report on modifying the gate electrode of OECT with molecularly imprinted polymer (MIP) to achieve high selectivity with a ppb-level sensitivity.

In summary, the outcomes of this project have the potential to significantly impact the future of organic semiconductors. For instance, the hierarchical assembly method employed in the fabrication of centimeter-scale fibers offers an innovative approach to assembling molecules or nanostructures, especially those with small sizes or high flexibility that are difficult to directly control their orientations in electric field. Our research findings on chemical doping and morphology underscore the possibility of precisely controlling the rate and extent of chemical doping by manipulating the morphology and aggregation of conjugated polymers. Furthermore, the introduction of molecularly imprinted polymer (MIP) modifications to organic electrochemical transistor (OECT) devices holds promise for real-time molecule detection within biocompatible environments. Additionally, this project has played a vital role in enhancing the research infrastructure at the University of Southern Mississippi. It has provided valuable research training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, nurturing the next generation of STEM professionals. Notably, two Ph.D. dissertations directly benefited from the support provided by NSF.


Last Modified: 09/21/2023
Modified by: Song Guo
